name: (2E)-3-(5-bromo-8-nitronaphthalen-1-yl)prop-2-enoic acid
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1466

name: (2E)-3-(5-bromo-8-nitronaphthalen-1-yl)prop-2-enoic acid
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1466
Reason: The basic unit naphthalene has a melting point of 80 degrees Celsius. The functional groups in the target compound would have the following estimated effects on the melting point: a nitro group introduces strong dipoles and potential for intermolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonding, which could increase the melting point significantly, estimated at +50 degrees Celsius; a bromine atom, being a large halogen, can increase van der Waals interactions, estimated at +20 degrees Celsius; an alkenyl group generally does not have a significant impact on melting point, so it would be estimated at +/-0; the carboxylic acid group has the potential for strong hydrogen bonding which might increase the melting point substantially, estimated at +40 degrees Celsius. When we combine these adjustments, we predict an overall increase.

name: (2E)-3-(5-bromo-8-nitronaphthalen-1-yl)prop-2-enoic acid
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1466
Reason: The basic unit naphthalene has a melting point of 80 degrees Celsius. Introducing a nitro group adds strong dipoles and potential for hydrogen bonding, which significantly increases the melting point; this could be estimated at +30 degrees Celsius. The presence of a bromine atom contributes to increased van der Waals forces due to its larger atomic size, estimated at +10 degrees Celsius. An alkenyl group does not significantly affect the melting point and can be considered neutral in this context, so its effect is estimated at 0 degrees Celsius. A carboxylic acid group is capable of strong hydrogen bonding, which should also significantly increase the melting point; this could be estimated at +20 degrees Celsius. By summing up these contributions, we obtain the predicted melting point increment.
